awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Collaborative Research: Data-driven Stratification and  Prognosis for Traumatic Brain Injury
awd_abstract_narration:
Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI) is a global health problem affecting over 10 million people worldwide and is a leading cause of death and disability among children and young adults in the United States. While the understanding of biological mechanisms related to acquired brain injuries has improved significantly in the past two decades, none of these advances have translated to a successful clinical trial and therefore, there has been no substantial improvement in treating such critical conditions. The heterogeneity of TBI and the ability to reliably stratify critically-ill patients who will likely have better outcomes for a certain intervention are amongst the major challenges in clinical research. To address these challenges, this project develops a comprehensive set of machine learning methods that can be broadly applied to a variety of problems. Data sources include both in-patient bedside data as well as remotely monitored telemedicine data, thus connecting data at multiple levels for specific patient populations. This research is crucial to support the development of pilot computational models for stratification of critical care patients and potentially inform ways to reduce the overall healthcare and societal costs for this patient population.

The project aims to develop novel computational algorithms for reliably stratifying brain injury patients and predicting their short-term and long-term outcomes from multi-modal physiologic and clinical data. Specifically, the research objectives of this project are: (i) Develop a scalable and effective algorithm for personalized subgroup identification for any given patient using an efficient subcluster model that groups patients using only a subset of coherently relevant variables. Discriminative subspace models will also be built to distinguish subgroups of patients. (ii) Propose a new machine learning paradigm called 'Label-Bag learning' to identify and predict changes in TBI Patients. The goal of label-bag learning is to learn a group of labels and their corresponding outcome variable in the data. The project includes a new framework based on Bayesian correlations that can adaptively transform any existing machine learning algorithm and implicitly handle this label-bag problem formulation through constrained modeling. (iii) Develop a novel approach to long-term outcome prediction through differential subset modeling framework. Through outreach and educational activities, the project will promote computational and systems thinking among high school, undergraduate, and graduate students along with clinical trainees. Methods developed in this project will be integrated into courses and tutorials that have both computational and biomedical emphases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of the project is to develop clinically relevant informatics-based tools and novel computational algorithms, broadly, for critical care. Within critical care, brain trauma is the major application area for this project. As a collaborative research project across four sites – Virginia Polytechnic & State University (VTech), University of Arizona (UArizona), Emory University, and University of Cincinnati (UC) – the focus of the project was to develop new and sophisticated methods that can reliably stratify critical care patients, such as those with Traumatic Brain Injury (TBI), acute respiratory failure, or acute heart failure, for targeted therapies and to accurately predict their prognosis are central to the motivation of this work. More specifically, this project developed solutions for complex tasks of identifying clinical subgroups, predicting short-term and long-term outcomes of critically ill patients from multimodal physiologic and clinical data, as well as interpreting and explaining model behavior for users. The specific aims of this project were to: (1) develop scalable and effective algorithms for subgroup identification for critical care patients using efficient subspace clustering methods; (2) propose a machine learning paradigm to identify and predict neurodeterioration and other forms of decompensation in critical care patients; (3) develop interpretable models for long-term outcome prediction in intensive care units; and (4) generate new clinically-relevant knowledge and information for a wide range of critical care conditions. As part of this project, our teams have developed several innovative solutions that have significantly advanced the current technologies used in solving these clinical challenges. We developed a Transformer-based model for prediction tasks on multivariate clinical time-series, tackling sparsity and sporadicity challenges faced by existing aggregation and imputation methods. We also built a model-agnostic explanation method that is computationally efficient and interpretable for prediction tasks in clinical time-series data using TBI as a case study. Results obtained from this 4-year project were disseminated to (1) the clinical communities of interest through the TRACK-TBI ICU working group and advisory board members, (2) informatics and engineering communities through journal publications and conference proceedings (which are made publicly available through the NSF project website), and (3) various industry and local communities through regional public events.


Last Modified: 03/19/2023
Modified by: Chandan K Reddy
